div.p: An edition of the Beethoven piano sonatas with Urlinie graphs, planned by Schenker and Hertzka in 1922 but never carried out.

An "Urlinie-Ausgabe" of the Beethoven piano sonatas is not mentioned in Schenker's analytical essay on the first sonata, Op. 2, No. 1, in F minor, published in Tonwille 2. The expression suggests the provision of analytical commentary, but all that Schenker promised here was "to give a textual report of my edition of the remaining sonatas, where possible" (p. 36; Eng. transl., vol. 1, p. 83). He goes on, however, to clarify his view of what editing a sonata entails: This immediately brings up the last and most difficult questions of the given content, as well as of musical culture in general. As little as one may say of Beethoven himself that he was merely practicing musical philology when he sought the best notation, improved slurs, etc., just as little may the work of an editor in this matter be regarded as philology. It is rather of a purely artistic nature, and demands the full interest of all those who want to make the content of the work of art truly their own. (Tonwille 2, 36â€“37; Eng. transl., vol. 1, p.83.) That is, for Schenker the distinction between understanding the content of a work (analysis) and making informed editorial decisions when confronted with textually discrepant sources for it (editorial technique simply did not exist).
